metadata.title: NBA CBA Study Materials - Batch 4: Article XI - Free Agency
metadata.importance: CRITICAL - Agents must master free agency rules

studyNote: Article XI is ESSENTIAL for agents. Understanding the difference between Restricted and Unrestricted Free Agency, qualifying offers, and the Right of First Refusal is fundamental to representing players.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between Restricted and Unrestricted Free Agency?
options: Current team's right to match any offer for Restricted FAs
questions.explanation: The key difference is that a Restricted Free Agent's current team has the Right of First Refusal - they can match any offer sheet and retain the player. Unrestricted Free Agents can sign anywhere.

questions.question: What is a Qualifying Veteran Free Agent?
options: A player who played for the same team for 3+ consecutive years
questions.explanation: A Qualifying Veteran Free Agent is a player who spent 3 consecutive years with the same team (without being waived or changing teams as a free agent) before becoming a free agent.
questions.source: Article XI, Section 1(e) & Article I, Section 1(yy)

questions.question: What is an Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent?
options: A player who spent 2 consecutive years with the same team
questions.explanation: An Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent is a player who played for the same team for 2 consecutive years (vs 3 years for full Qualifying status).
questions.source: Article XI, Section 1(e) & Article I, Section 1(t)

questions.question: When does the NBA free agency period officially begin?
options: After the Moratorium Period ends (typically July 6 at 12:01 PM Eastern)
questions.explanation: The Moratorium Period runs from July 1-6. Contracts can be negotiated during this time but cannot be signed until 12:01 PM Eastern on the last day of the Moratorium (typically July 6).

questions.question: What can happen during the Moratorium Period (July 1-6)?
options: Teams can negotiate with free agents but cannot sign contracts
questions.explanation: During the Moratorium, teams can negotiate agreements with free agents and trades can be agreed upon, but no contracts can be officially signed until the Moratorium ends.

questions.question: What is a Qualifying Offer?
options: A required one-year offer a team must make to make their player a Restricted Free Agent
questions.explanation: A Qualifying Offer is a required one-year contract offer that a team must extend to certain free agents by a deadline to make them Restricted Free Agents with Right of First Refusal.

questions.question: By when must a team extend a Qualifying Offer to make a player a Restricted Free Agent?
options: By the end of the Moratorium
questions.explanation: Teams must extend Qualifying Offers by June 30 at 11:59 PM Eastern to retain the Right of First Refusal and make the player a Restricted Free Agent.

questions.question: What is an Offer Sheet?
options: A written contract offer from a new team to a Restricted Free Agent that the player's current team can match
questions.explanation: An Offer Sheet is a formal contract offer from a new team to a Restricted Free Agent. The player's Prior Team has the Right of First Refusal to match it.

questions.question: How long does a team have to match an Offer Sheet for a Restricted Free Agent?
questions.explanation: The Prior Team has 48 hours from receiving the Offer Sheet to decide whether to match it and retain the player or let him go to the new team.

questions.question: If a team matches an Offer Sheet, what are the contract terms?
options: Team must match it exactly - same salary, years, and terms
questions.explanation: When exercising the Right of First Refusal, the Prior Team must match the Offer Sheet exactly - same compensation, same years, same terms.

questions.question: Can a player sign an Offer Sheet and then back out before the Prior Team matches?
options: No, once signed the Offer Sheet is binding (subject to Prior Team's right to match)
questions.explanation: Once a Restricted Free Agent signs an Offer Sheet, it becomes binding. The player cannot withdraw - either the Prior Team matches or the player goes to the new team.

questions.question: What happens if a Restricted Free Agent receives no Offer Sheet by the end of the Moratorium?
options: Can only sign the Qualifying Offer
Can sign with any team and Prior Team retains matching rights all season
questions.explanation: If no Offer Sheet is signed during the Moratorium, the player remains a Restricted Free Agent all season. The Prior Team retains matching rights for any Offer Sheet signed later.

questions.question: Can a team extend the deadline for a player to accept a Qualifying Offer?
options: Yes, team can extend until March 1
questions.explanation: Teams can extend the Qualifying Offer acceptance deadline until March 1, which allows them to keep the player restricted longer into the season.

questions.question: What happens if a Restricted Free Agent accepts the Qualifying Offer?
options: Signs a one-year deal with the Prior Team for the QO amount
questions.explanation: If a player accepts the Qualifying Offer, they sign a one-year contract with their Prior Team for the QO amount and become an Unrestricted Free Agent the following summer.

questions.question: Can a player negotiate with multiple teams simultaneously during free agency?
options: Yes, players (and their agents) can negotiate with multiple teams at once
questions.explanation: Free agents and their agents are permitted to negotiate with multiple teams simultaneously during the free agency period.

questions.question: What is the minimum salary for a Qualifying Offer for most players?
questions.explanation: For most Restricted Free Agents, the Qualifying Offer must be at least 125% of the player's prior season salary (with some exceptions for specific circumstances).

questions.question: Can Unrestricted Free Agents sign with any team during the Moratorium?
options: No, must wait until Moratorium ends to officially sign
questions.explanation: While negotiations can occur during the Moratorium, no contracts (restricted or unrestricted) can be officially signed until the Moratorium ends.

questions.question: What is a 'Non-Qualifying Veteran Free Agent'?
options: A veteran who doesn't meet the 2 or 3 year tenure requirements with his Prior Team
questions.explanation: A Non-Qualifying Veteran Free Agent is a player who became a free agent but didn't spend enough consecutive time with their Prior Team to qualify as an Early Qualifying or Qualifying Veteran Free Agent.

questions.question: Can a team sign-and-trade a free agent?
options: Yes, team can re-sign their own free agent and immediately trade him
questions.explanation: Sign-and-trade transactions allow a team to re-sign its own free agent and simultaneously trade him to another team, benefiting all parties involved.

questions.question: What restriction applies to teams acquiring players via sign-and-trade?
options: They are hard-capped at the First Apron for that season
questions.explanation: Teams that acquire a player via sign-and-trade are hard-capped at the First Apron for the entire season - they absolutely cannot exceed it.

questions.question: When can teams first contact free agents?
questions.explanation: The 'legal tampering period' begins on June 30 at 6:00 PM Eastern, allowing teams to officially contact and negotiate with free agents before the Moratorium.

questions.question: What is 'tampering' in the context of free agency?
options: Illegal contact with players under contract or before the legal tampering period
questions.explanation: Tampering is when teams make unauthorized contact with players who are under contract with another team or before the legal tampering period begins.

questions.question: Can a player under contract negotiate with other teams?
options: No, it's prohibited until they become a free agent
Only in the last year of contract
questions.explanation: Players under contract cannot negotiate with other teams. This would constitute tampering and is prohibited until the player becomes a free agent.

questions.question: What happens to a player's free agent rights if he plays overseas after his contract ends?
options: Becomes Unrestricted Free Agent when he returns
questions.explanation: If a free agent plays overseas, he remains a free agent. When he decides to return to the NBA, he's still an Unrestricted Free Agent unless his Prior Team retained specific rights.

questions.question: Can a team withdraw a Qualifying Offer after extending it?
options: No, once extended it cannot be withdrawn
questions.explanation: Once a team extends a Qualifying Offer, it cannot be withdrawn. The offer remains valid and the player can accept it at any time before the deadline.

questions.question: What is the maximum length of an Offer Sheet to a Restricted Free Agent?
questions.explanation: Offer Sheets to Restricted Free Agents (from teams other than the Prior Team) are limited to a maximum of 4 years, while the Prior Team can offer up to 5 years using Bird Rights.

questions.question: If a player becomes a free agent at age 35, are there special considerations?
options: Yes, special 'Over 38' contract rules may apply for longer deals
questions.explanation: For players 35-36 signing contracts that extend past age 38, special 'Over 38' rules apply affecting how salary is allocated for cap purposes.

questions.question: Can a Restricted Free Agent sign an Offer Sheet that includes a player option?
options: No, Offer Sheets cannot include player options or Early Termination Options
questions.explanation: Offer Sheets to Restricted Free Agents cannot include player options or Early Termination Options (ETOs) to prevent manipulation of the matching process.

questions.question: What happens if a player and team cannot agree on whether a player is Restricted or Unrestricted?
options: Dispute goes to the System Arbitrator
questions.explanation: Disputes about free agent status (Restricted vs Unrestricted) are resolved by the System Arbitrator through the grievance and arbitration process.

questions.question: Can a team renounce a Restricted Free Agent to create cap space?
questions.explanation: Teams can renounce their restricted free agents to create cap space, but doing so makes the player an Unrestricted Free Agent whom they can only re-sign using cap room or minimum exception.

questions.question: What is 'cap hold' for free agents?
options: Amount that counts against the cap while player is a free agent
questions.explanation: A free agent's 'cap hold' is an amount that counts against the team's salary cap until the player signs elsewhere or is renounced, based on the player's prior salary.

questions.question: Can a player accept a Qualifying Offer and then try to renegotiate during the season?
options: No, one-year QO contracts cannot be renegotiated or extended
questions.explanation: Contracts signed as Qualifying Offers are for one year and cannot be renegotiated or extended. The player will become an Unrestricted Free Agent the following summer.

questions.question: What is a 'Maximum Qualifying Offer'?
options: A special QO for certain Rookie Scale players who meet performance criteria (MVP, All-NBA, etc.)
questions.explanation: A Maximum Qualifying Offer is a special QO that must be made to certain Rookie Scale players who earned specific honors (MVP, DPOY, 2x All-NBA), allowing the team to make them Restricted.

questions.question: If a team matches an Offer Sheet, when does the new contract begin?
options: Depends on the Offer Sheet terms - could be immediate or next season
questions.explanation: The matched contract begins whenever the Offer Sheet specified - some Offer Sheets are for the current season, others for the following season.

questions.question: Can agents negotiate with teams on behalf of players who are still under contract?
questions.explanation: Agents cannot negotiate with other teams on behalf of players under contract. This would be tampering and violates CBA and NBPA regulations.

questions.question: What percentage of players typically become Unrestricted vs Restricted Free Agents?
options: Majority become Unrestricted (most are either QVFAs/EQVFAs with their teams or have insufficient tenure)
questions.explanation: Most free agents are either Unrestricted (sufficient tenure with their team qualifying them for Bird Rights) or are made Unrestricted by teams not extending Qualifying Offers.

questions.question: Can a player's agent begin negotiating during the legal tampering period?
options: No, must wait for player to do it
Yes, agents can negotiate on behalf of their clients starting at 6PM ET on June 30
questions.explanation: During the legal tampering period (starting June 30 at 6PM ET), agents can negotiate on behalf of their free agent clients with any team.

questions.question: If a Restricted Free Agent signs an Offer Sheet during the season (after the Moratorium), how long does the Prior Team have to match?
questions.explanation: The Prior Team has 48 hours to match an Offer Sheet regardless of when during the year it's signed (Moratorium or regular season).

questions.question: What happens if a team fails to extend a Qualifying Offer to a player they want to keep as a Restricted Free Agent?
options: Player becomes Unrestricted Free Agent immediately
Can extend it late with penalty
questions.explanation: If a team misses the June 30 deadline to extend a Qualifying Offer, the player immediately becomes an Unrestricted Free Agent and the team loses matching rights.

questions.question: Can a player who accepts a Qualifying Offer become a free agent mid-season by requesting a trade?
options: No, they're under contract for the full season
questions.explanation: Accepting a Qualifying Offer creates a binding one-year contract. The player cannot become a free agent mid-season but will become an Unrestricted Free Agent the following summer.
